original_context: Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions.
Case does not excel in competition.
Case does not have good focus.
Case either reads tracks or anticipates turns, but not both, in order to excel in racing competitions.
If Case either shifts gears well or reads tracks effectively (but not both), then he excels in competition.
Every professional racer either takes risks or wins trophies (or both).
If Case either shifts gears well or takes risks on the track (but not both), then he can drive fast.
If Case has quick reflexes, then he can drive fast.
If Case is strategic, then he has quick reflexes and good focus.
Case is either aggressive or strategic (or both) on the track.
conclusion: Case is aggressive on the track.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake: The FOL statement is `p_11(Case) ⊕ p_4(Case)`. From the context, `p_4(Case)` means "Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions". Assuming `p_11(Case)` means "Case reads tracks" (or "Case reads tracks effectively" as suggested by its use in other statements), the FOL translates to "(Case reads tracks) XOR (Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions)". However, the natural language statement "Case either reads tracks or anticipates turns, but not both, in order to excel in racing competitions" implies that the purpose "in order to excel..." applies to the entire XORed action of "reading tracks" and "anticipating turns".  The FOL only incorporates this purpose for the "anticipates turns" part (via `p_4`) and not for the "reads tracks" part. The NL would be better represented as `(reads_tracks(Case) ⊕ anticipates_turns(Case)) → excels(Case)` or as `reads_tracks_to_excel(Case) ⊕ anticipates_turns_to_excel(Case)`. The given FOL does not match these interpretations because `p_11(Case)` does not inherently include "in order to excel".

openai/gpt-4.1.mistake: None – the mapping is correct. The inclusive 'or' is captured in both FOL and NL.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake: The FOL statement `p_11(Case) ⊕ p_4(Case)`, when `p_11(Case)` is interpreted as "Case reads tracks" (a new predicate not defined in context facts) and `p_4(Case)` is defined from context as "Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions", results in a meaning of: "(Case reads tracks) XOR (Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions)". In this FOL statement, the purpose "in order to excel..." is intrinsically linked only to the action of "anticipating turns" and not to "reading tracks". However, the natural language statement "Case either reads tracks or anticipates turns, but not both, in order to excel in racing competitions" most naturally implies that the purpose ("in order to excel...") applies to the _entire_ compound action of "(Case reads tracks) XOR (Case anticipates turns)". The scope of the purpose clause is different, leading to a mismatch in meaning.

openai/gpt-4.1.mistake: None. The FOL and NL are equivalent because the biconditional is expressed as two if statements in natural language.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake: The FOL `p_11(Case) ⊕ p_4(Case)` translates to an exclusive disjunction: 'Either Case reads tracks (represented by `p_11(Case)`) OR Case anticipates turns in order to excel in racing competitions (represented by `p_4(Case)`), but not both.' The natural language statement 'Case either reads tracks or anticipates turns, but not both, in order to excel in racing competitions' implies that the purpose ('in order to excel in racing competitions') applies to the entire choice between 'reads tracks' and 'anticipates turns'. In the FOL, this purpose is embedded only within the definition of `p_4(Case)` and is not explicitly linked to `p_11(Case)` or to the outcome of the XOR operation necessarily resulting in excelling. The NL suggests that both 'reading tracks' and 'anticipating turns' are actions one of which is chosen *for the purpose of* excelling, while the FOL only has this purpose baked into one of the options.

google/gemini-2.5-pro-preview.mistake: The NL implies an implicational structure: `(reads_tracks ⊕ anticipates_turns) → excels_in_competition`. The FOL is a simple XOR: `reads_tracks_effectively ⊕ (anticipates_turns_in_order_to_excel)`. The scope and role of 'in order to excel in racing competitions' are different. In the NL, it is presented as a purpose or consequence of the XORed actions. In the FOL, this phrase is embedded within one of the predicates (`p_4(Case)`) participating in the XOR operation, not as a result of the XOR itself.
